left_text: Labial palpus with ﬁrst two segments elongate (Fig. 33-1a), ﬂattened, the last two segments small, usually diverging laterally from axis of ﬁrst two, not ﬂattened, rarely absent; galeal comb absent or rarely weakly indicated; stipital comb and concavity commonly present (Figs. 19-1a, 33-1b); galeal blade elongate, commonly as long as or longer than stipes (Fig. 33-1b); volsella frequently absent or difﬁcult to recognize, rarely with distinct digitus and cuspis [L-T (long-tongued) bees]
right_text: Labial palpus with the four segments similar to one another (Fig. 33-1c), or ﬁrst or rarely ﬁrst two elongate but not much ﬂattened; galeal comb commonly present; stipital comb and concavity absent (Fig. 33-1d); galeal blade usually shorter than stipes (Fig. 33-1d); volsella commonly well developed, usually with recognizable digitus and cuspis [S-T (short-tongued) bees]

left_text: Labrum with basolateral angles enlarged, base forming broad articulation with clypeus, labrum thus widest at base (Fig. 33-2a); labrum at least 0.8 times as long as broad and usually as long as broad or longer; forewing with two submarginal cells, usually about equal in length (except with three in Fideliini); scopa, when present, restricted to metasomal sterna
right_text: Labrum with basolateral angles little developed, articu lation with clypeus thus narrower than full width of labrum (Fig. 33-2b); labrum usually broader than long, but in some parasitic forms (where scopa is absent) labrum elongate; forewing with two or three submarginal cells, rarely only one; scopa, when present, on hind leg, particularly the tibia, and usually absent on metasomal sterna

left_text: Glossa pointed at apex, sometimes with ﬂabellum
right_text: Glossa bluntly rounded, truncate, or bilobed at apex (except pointed in males of three hylaeine genera from Australia-New Guinea area); ﬂabellum absent

left_text: Lacinia represented by scalelike lobe with hairs near base of galea (Fig. 33-1b, d); mentum and lorum forming proboscidial lobe (Figs. 33-3b-f, 33-4b), both at least partly sclerotized; lorum not ﬂat
right_text: Lacinia inconspicuous or displaced, not a scalelike lobe at base of galea (Fig. 21-2a, b); mentum and lorum not forming proboscidial lobe (Figs. 33-3h, i, 34-4a), mentum sometimes membranous; lorum membranous or nearly ﬂat sclerotized membrane (apron) between cardines (Figs. 33-3h, 33-4a)

left_text: Lorum more or less platelike but produced in middle for attachment to base of mentum; facial fovea present in females (Fig. 33-2c) and some males, fovea sometimes a groove rather than broad as in ﬁgure; subantennal area almost always deﬁned by two subantennal sutures below each antennal socket (Fig. 33-2c)
right_text: Lorum slender, V-shaped or Y-shaped, as in L-T bees (Fig. 33-1a); facial fovea absent; a single subantennal suture below each antennal socket (as in Fig. 33-2d)

left_text: Lacinia a small, hairless sclerite hidden between expanded stipites; subantennal area deﬁned by two subantennal sutures below each antennal socket (as in Fig. 332c); stigma nearly absent; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment as long as scape or longer
right_text: Lacinia represented by small, hairy lobe on anterior surface of labiomaxillary tube above rest of maxilla (Fig. 212a); a single subantennal suture below each antennal socket (Fig. 33-2d); stigma well developed; ﬁrst ﬂagellar segment much shorter than scape

left_text: Apex of glossa bluntly rounded, without preapical fringe or apical glossal lobes; episternal groove absent below scrobal groove; scopa present on hind tibia, but absent on femur
right_text: Apex of glossa truncate to bilobed (except pointed in males of three genera in Australia-New Guinea region); episternal groove usually present below scrobal groove; scopa, when present, well developed on hind femur as well as tibia
